Award.AwardTitle: Hunger-Dependent Modulation of Olfactory Receptor Gene Expression
Award.AbstractNarration:
Animals change their behavior in an ever-changing environment in order to survive and reproduce. The researchers are trying to understand how changes in the environment can alter behavior. Studies have shown that an animal's sensory perception of attractive and noxious chemical stimuli in its environment can dramatically alter its behavior according to its feeding state. These behavioral modifications could allow them to alter and optimize their food-search strategies. Growing evidence suggests that an animal's feeding state can alter its sensory perception directly by changing the expression levels of chemoreceptor genes. Thus, an important question is to understand how these expression changes may contribute to changes in an animal's behavior. This research investigates, for the first time, the mechanisms by which chemoreceptor genes in a single sensory neuron type are regulated by an animal's feeding state. Since disease-carrying mosquitoes change the expression of chemoreceptor genes as a function of their feeding state, this research will also provide the basis for novel strategies to control chemical-driven host-seeking behavior in these systems.

The researchers investigate the mechanisms of how an animal's feeding state can alter chemosensory behaviors by modulating the expression of chemoreceptor genes. With help of a feeding state-dependent reporter assay to monitor changes in chemoreceptor gene expression combined with genetic, genomic and behavioral approaches in C. elegans, this project will investigate the mechanisms by which the expression of this chemoreceptor gene in a single sensory neuron type, ADL, is modulated by feeding state via insulin and neuropeptide signaling. Genetic approaches will be used to identify potential transcriptional factors required for the expression of this chemoreceptor gene. Behavioral assays will be used to examine whether an altered expression of chemoreceptor genes contributes to altered ADL-mediated responses as a function of feeding state. Lastly, the transcriptional profile of the ADL neuron in starved animals will identify additional genes that provide new targets of regulators of altered behaviors upon starvation. The results of this project will provide critical information into the molecular and neural mechanisms of chemoreceptor gene expression, and the basic mechanisms underlying behavioral plasticity. This research will support the research training of undergraduate and graduate students from low-income and disadvantaged backgrounds. This research will also create a 'Sense of Smell Day' for K-12 students as part of Brain Awareness Week in Nevada to teach young explorers in the lab the basics of how the sense of smell works.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Animals modify their behavior based on external and internal state signals, such as hunger. However, the neural and molecular mechanisms that underlie this plasticity in behavior are poorly understood. Chemosensory basis of behavioral plasticity in response to dietary signals and internal nutritional need has been observed in a wide range of animals, which allows them to identify suitable food sources and avoid harmful environments. We and others hypothesized that plasticity in chemosensory behavior may, in part, be contributed by dynamic changes in the expression of chemosensory receptor genes localized in the sensory nervous system, which could allow animals to modify their behavior in response to changes in their internal feeding state. We investigated how animals modulate the gene expression of chemosensory receptors localized in the sensory nervous system using the C. elegans nematode as a model system. Its well-described and mapped nervous system, coupled to its completely sequenced genome allowed us to interrogate the neural circuits and signaling pathways that animals use underlying this chemoreceptor gene modulation. As such, we used a single chemoreceptor gene (srh-234), which is localized and expressed in a single sensory neuron type (ADL) in C. elegans. Our work in this project discovered that srh-234 transcription in ADL neurons is altered in different feeding state conditions; that is srh-234 expression is high when animals are fed, but low when animals are starved. We first characterized this feeding state-dependent transcription of chemoreceptor expression. We found a transcriptional module consisting of MEF2 and basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) factors that act in ADL neurons to regulate srh-234 expression, and this expression can also be remotely regulated by bHLH factors acting in the gut. We also showed that sensory inputs into ADL neurons (i.e. food presence) and circuit inputs from RMG interneurons that are electrically coupled to ADL neurons are required to modulate srh-234 expression. This sensory- and circuit-mediated regulation of srh-234 involves the neuropeptide Y receptor homolog acting in RMG interneurons, and the insulin-like receptor acting ADL neurons. We further show that insulin signals from the gut can regulate srh-234 expression in ADL neurons. Combined our results were published in 3 peer-reviewed manuscripts.

In summary, key outcomes from this project illustrated that sensory neuron-gut communications via distinct insulin signals play a key role in the modulation of chemoreceptor gene expression. Our results further revealed a complex but yet intriguing neural and molecular mechanism by which chemoreceptor genes are turned on and off at the level of transcription in single sensory neuron types, which could be an effective strategy by which animals fine-tune their chemosensory responses in different feeding state conditions. Outcomes from this work could have implications for other systems, as dynamic changes in olfactory receptor gene expression is observed in disease-carrying mosquitos in response to feeding state, as well as in fruit flies and fish.

Other measured outcomes over the period of the project were educational and training activities, and the dissemination of knowledge to both the science and broader community. Two graduate students earned their doctoral degree and obtained postdoctoral positions at UCSF and the University of Pennsylvania. Graduate students were recognized by scholarship awards such as the Molecular Biosciences Berner Scholarship award (University of Nevada, Reno), and the Dean Merit Scholarship Award of UNR Graduate School. One graduate student was a finalist in the 3-minute thesis competition at UNR. More than 10 undergraduate and high-school students were part of the project, and either completed their honor or senior theses, obtained authorships on the peer-reviewed manuscripts, or were recognized by scholarships and awards. Of the undergrads, three went to Medical Schools (UNR, UNLV, USC), two went to Graduate School (UNR, University of Utah), and others moved on to non-academic careers. Dissemination of knowledge took place during the period by presenting posters and oral presentations at local, national and international conferences, seminars and annual graduate symposia open to the public. The students and the PI organized and led outreach activities for K12 students and the general public, such as Day with a Scientist, Brain Awareness Week in Nevada, and live scientific demonstrations and Social Science events at the Children Discovery Museum in Reno, Nevada.
